intro: Rhododendron ferrugineum var. variegatum, commonly known as the variegated heath, is a low-growing evergreen shrub native to the mountainous regions of Europe. It is characterized by its dense, leathery leaves that exhibit a distinctive variegation of green and white or silver markings. The plant produces showy, bell-shaped flowers in shades of pink, red, or white, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in heathland and moorland environments. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is a popular species in horticulture and conservation efforts.
